Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Language Access and Gendered Mobility

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports a linguistic anthropological investigation into the relationship between language proficiency and women's economic and social empowerment in multi-language environments. Social scientists have found that even when women have increased access to education and economic opportunities, their mobility may be limited. They may be held back not only by general social and cultural norms but also more particularly by the lack of access to key mobility infrastructures, such as the ability to communicate in a world language, that these norms produce. Without these language skills, they are unable to reach their full potential in globalized economies. This project will look at how women negotiate multi-language situations and under what conditions they are successful in obtaining world language competencies.

The research will be carried out in the United Arab Emirates (UAE) because it provides a super-diverse multinational setting where English is the crucial conduit for communication and business transactions. The research will be conducted by University of Texas anthropology doctoral student Deina A. Rabie, who is supervised by linguistic anthropologist Dr. Elizabeth L. Keating. Rabie will collect data in domestic, social, educational, and commercial settings, including daily market and service transactions, formal corporate contexts of international business and communication, family gatherings, religious meetings, and classrooms. She will sample and analyze naturally occurring speech; conduct semi-structured interviews; carry out linguistic, spatial, and sonic mappings; analyze relevant media; and consult materials collected in the national oral history of the National Archives of the United Arab Emirates. Findings from this research will contribute to theorizing new dimensions of gender in globalized contexts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Deina Rabie has completed research for her dissertation “The English Channel: Language and Gendered Mobility among Emirati Women in the United Arab Emirates,” supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. During her funding period, she spent twelve months in Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates. As a linguistic anthropologist, Rabie was interested in studying how first and second-generation female Emirati university graduates have used English language acquisition, especially through the country’s English-medium higher education system, to gain professional, social, and economic mobility in the UAE’s English-dominant multinational workforce.

The UAE was chosen as the key site of the research because of its compelling demographic landscape. As a young country that is only forty-seven years old and one of the world’s top oil exporters, the UAE provides work and residence to 85% of its population who hail from 202 different countries and speak over 70 different native languages. Emiratis, the UAE’s 15% native minority, have elite status as its only citizens and recipients of welfare subsidies from oil income. Since the creation of the UAE nation state in 1971, these welfare benefits from oil income have been channeled to families solely through Emirati men, who have also been the primary beneficiaries of growth in state employment while holding only secondary school diplomas. Prior to fieldwork, the researcher hypothesized that as oil welfare subsidies channeled to male family members have begun to decrease amid a shifting post-oil company, Emirati women have had a greater stake in pursuing the country’s English-medium higher education to gain positions in corporate multinationals alongside Emirati men and other expatriates. Through ethnographic and linguistic research methods, the researcher used her fieldwork tenure to examine the types of mobility English-mediated modes of circulation--or linguistic infrastructures--especially in the domains of higher education, the work place, and media, enable for Emirati women and the implications of such mobility on relational and gender ideologies in domestic, social, and professional domains. 

Rabie’s Emirati female interlocutors were employed at educational and corporate multinationals and ranged in age from twenty-two to forty-five years old. Through participant observation, semi-structured interviews, media analysis, and archival research, she observed significant elements shared by all her interlocutors and key subjective departures among younger participants in their twenties to mid-thirties. All interlocutors expressed a great degree of functional multilingualism in Arabic, English and other languages, like Urdu and Tagalog, to meet the highly diverse landscape they inhabited. Moreover, the vast majority of participants showed pride in being Emirati, supported state development initiatives, and felt a deep responsibility to represent the UAE and participate in its multinational workforce. However, older participants demonstrated compartmentalized usage of English as the language of the workplace and their professional lives while maintaining distinct and segregated lives with extended patriarchal family networks where Arabic is the dominant language of interaction and religious practice. Younger interlocutors exhibited a more fluid relationship with the language and its attendant social networks, identifying as fluent or bilingual in English. Moreover, unlike their older counterparts who had immediate expectations of occupying managerial positions in the public sector, they followed more merit based promotional techniques in private multinationals. They were also more likely to pursue social relationships with other English-speaking white-collar expatriates and have the opportunity and permission to travel alone for work and leisure. Interlocutors in their twenties, especially, expressed more flexibility and choice in the wearing of the traditional black scarf and outer cloak. Furthermore, though espousing the country’s strategic plans, younger interlocutors preferred a more pluralistic form of governance, and many participated in the state’s mediated youth circles and followed social media platforms in Arabic and English that focused on salient social issues. These changes correspond to a shift away from arranged marriage practices and segregated extended family structures to nuclear family residences among other white-collar expatriates.

To conclude, while Arabic continues to occupy a vital role as the language of the government as well as its religion and culture, these English-mediated networks have influenced more visible changes in comportment and appearance and interpersonal relationships that veer away from the kind of welfare enabled national distinction as well as ethnic and gender segregation practiced by the older generations. These findings provide ethnographic evidence for the impacts of the UAE’s Economic Vision 2030 of providing a highly skilled, highly productive national workforce through educational reform and increase in private sector employment, especially for women. Furthermore, this research is an important contribution to studies on neoliberal higher education and global white and pink-collar employment dependent upon English language proficiency, and the concomitant shifts in the social orders of gender and power in actors’ journeys towards global capitalism. In particular, framing language in terms of infrastructure centers linguistically mediated modes of circulation and mobility in state and private networks as processes through which subject positions emerge.
